title: 104_s598
content: The Act titled "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995" increases taxes on tobacco products. The "Tobacco Consumption Reduction and Health Improvement Act of 1995" raises taxes on cigars and cigarettes. For cigars, the tax rate is increased to $5.8125 per thousand, and for large cigars weighing more than 3 pounds per thousand, the tax is 65.875% of the selling price but not exceeding $155 per thousand. The tax rates on cigarettes are increased to $62 per thousand and $130.20 per thousand for different categories. Additionally, the tax rate on cigarette papers is amended to 3.875 cents, and the tax rate on cigarette tubes is amended to 1.5 cents. The tax rates on smokeless tobacco products are increased, with rates for snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco being amended to $1.86, $0.62, and $3.4875 respectively. The amendments made by this subsection apply to various tobacco products removed after December 31, 1995. A tax of $1.86 per pound is imposed on roll-your-own tobacco manufactured or imported into the United States. The definition of 'roll-your-own tobacco' is clarified as tobacco suitable for making cigarettes. Amendments include adding roll-your-own tobacco to the tax code and specifying its characteristics. The definition of 'roll-your-own tobacco' is clarified as tobacco suitable for making cigarettes. Amendments include adding roll-your-own tobacco to the tax code for personal consumption. The tax code is amended to include roll-your-own tobacco for personal consumption under chapter 52. The tax code amendments in Chapter 52 apply to roll-your-own tobacco and related products, with an effective date after December 31, 1995. A transitional rule is in place for manufacturers and importers who submit applications before January 1, 1996. Pending final action on an application under Chapter 52, a business can continue operations. All provisions of Chapter 52 apply to the applicant as if they held a permit. Floor stocks of certain tobacco products are subject to taxes if held for sale before January 1, 1996. Taxes are imposed on small and large cigars, as well as small and large cigarettes, based on weight and price. Taxes are imposed on small and large cigars, as well as small and large cigarettes, based on weight and price. Cigarette papers are taxed at 3.125 cents for each 50 papers, while cigarette tubes are taxed at 6.25 cents for each 50 tubes. If papers or tubes exceed 6 1/2 inches in length, they are taxed accordingly. On tobacco products, taxes are imposed based on weight and type. Snuff is taxed at $1.50 per pound, chewing tobacco at 50 cents per pound, and pipe tobacco at $2.8125 per pound. The tax liability applies to individuals holding these products on January 1, 1996. Taxes on tobacco products are imposed based on weight and type, with specific rates for snuff, chewing tobacco, and pipe tobacco. Individuals holding these products on January 1, 1996, are liable for the tax, due and payable on February 15, 1996. The terms for various tobacco products are defined by specific subsections of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Taxes imposed on tobacco products do not apply to retail stocks held on January 1, 1996. Foreign trade zones have exceptions for certain tobacco products. The law exempts certain tobacco products from taxes if they were determined before January 1, 1996, and entered into the US from a foreign trade zone. Certain tobacco products placed under customs supervision before January 1, 1996, and entered into the US from a foreign trade zone are subject to tax. These products are treated as being held for sale on January 1, 1996. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding a new section to Subchapter A of chapter 98 relating to trust fund code. SEC. 9512. TOBACCO CONVERSION TRUST FUND. The Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund is established in the Treasury, funded by a percentage of revenue increases from tobacco-related amendments. The Trust Fund is available for the Secretary of Agriculture to use for designated expenditures. The Tobacco Conversion Trust Fund is established to provide assistance to farmers transitioning from tobacco to other crops and supporting economic diversification plans for communities and individuals involved in tobacco production. This includes government purchase of tobacco allotments for those choosing to exit tobacco production.
